document.masterDocTitle: The Italian species of the Chthonius ischnocheles group (Arachnida, Pseudoscorpiones, Chthoniidae), with reference to neighbouring countries

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Italian species of the Chthonius ischnocheles group (Arachnida, Pseudoscorpiones, Chthoniidae), with reference to neighbouring countries

bibRefCitation.author: Beier, M.
bibRefCitation.refString: Beier, M. (1951) Zur Kenntnis der ostalpinen Chthoniiden (Pseudoscorp.). Entomologisches Nachrichtenblatt, Wien, 3, 163 - 166.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality
: Austria , Salzburg ,
Krizersberg am Nordhang
des Untersberges ( 47°42’N , 12°59’E )
.
Distribution . Southern Germany ( Bavaria ), Austria , Croatia , Slovenia , North-central Italy .

Diagnosis ( ♂ ♀ ).
An eyed epigean
Chthonius
that differs from other species of the
ischnocheles
group in the following combination of characters: anterior margin of carapace with 1 or 2 preocular microsetae on each side; posterior margin of carapace with 2 macrosetae and 1 or 2 lateral microsetae; anterior eyes with convex lens; chelicerae with 1–3 lateral microsetae; chela length 0.57–0.84 mm ; movable chelal finger length 0.39–0.56 mm ; chelal fingers with contiguous teeth; fixed chelal finger with 47–62 teeth; ratio of pedipalpal femur/carapace 1.0–1.3.

Description of adults ( ♂ ♀ ).
Integument slightly pigmented, carapace, tergites, chelicerae and pedipalps pale brown; weak hispid granulation on lateral surfaces of carapace, on cheliceral palm and on base of fixed chelal finger. Carapace ( Fig. 28 ) 0.8–0.9 times longer than broad, trapezoidal, constricted posteriorly; anterior margin between median macrosetae with a prominent epistome in both sexes ( Figs 26–27 ); ocular area as in fig. 28, anterior eyes with convex lens (diameter
0.035 –0.045 mm
), posterior eyes with flat lens, all eyes with a tapetum; distance from anterior eyes to anterior margin of carapace
0.025 –0.035 mm
; standard chaetotaxy m 4m :6:4:2:m 2m (22), but note substantial variability in the number of preocular microsetae (m 4mm , mm 4mm , mm4mmm) and in both the number and length of microsetae on posterior margin of carapace (m2, m 2mm , mm 2mm ) even within the same population; length of anteromedian macrosetae 0.09–0.14 mm . Chaetotaxy of tergites 4:4:4:4:6:6:6:6:1T2T1:4:1T2T1:0. Chaetotaxy of sternites 10:(3)7–10(3):(2)7–8(2):8:6:6:6:6:2T1T2:0:2; genital opening of males flanked by 6–7 (rarely 5) setae on each side. Chelicerae ( Fig. 29 ) 1.9–2.1 ( ♂ ) or 1.9–2.05 ( ♀ ) times as long as broad, palm with 6 setae and 1–3 lateral microsetae; fixed finger with 7–10 teeth and 3–5 proximal microtubercles; movable finger with an isolated subapical tooth ( di ) at level with the spinneret, and 7–10 teeth proximally reduced in size; gs ratio 0.57–0.61; spinneret large and apically rounded, similar in both sexes ( Figs 29–30 ); rallum with 11 blades; serrulae interior and exterior with 12–14 and 15–17 blades respectively. Coxal setae: pedipalp 5 (including 2 on manducatory process), I 3 + 3 marginal microsetae, II 4, III 5, IV 6; coxa II with 5–9 coxal spines, coxa III with 3–5 coxal spines; intercoxal tubercle bisetose. Pedipalp: femur 4.2–4.9 ( ♂ ) or 4.2–4.8 ( ♀ ) times as long as broad, femoral chaetotaxy 3:5–6:2:5:1; chela ( Figs 33, 37 ) 4.9–5.8 ( ♂ ) or 4.8–5.3 ( ♀ ) times as long as deep; hand of chela 1.65–1.9 ( ♂ ) or 1.55–1.75 ( ♀ ) times as long as deep, ovoid in dorsal view ( Figs 31–32 ); fixed chelal finger with 47–62 contiguous teeth slightly inclined backwards, all cuspidate except the 6–12 proximal ones, which are apically rounded ( Figs 34–36, 38–40 ); all teeth with dental canal; base of fixed chelal finger with 2–4 microtubercles; fixed finger at level of est-it with 9–14 teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices
0.007 –0.011 mm
; tip of fixed chelal finger with apical sensilla af
1- 2
, distal paraxial seta gradually curved and thin; movable chelal finger with 36–50 contiguous teeth, cuspidate and reclined in the distal half of the finger, increasingly reduced towards finger base, reaching back near b (between sb and b they are mainly recognizable only by the presence of dental canal) ( Figs 34–36, 38–40 ); movable finger at level of st-t with 9–11 teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices
0.009 –0.011 mm
; coupled sensilla pc mainly just distad of sb , rarely at level of sb ; tip of movable chelal finger with apical sensilla am
1- 2
; trichobothria as in figs 33, 37; ratio sb -st/sb -b = 1.5–2.0; ratio of movable finger/hand of chela 1.8–2.1 ( ♂ ♀ ); ratio of pedipalpal femur/movable finger 0.9–1.0 ( ♂ ♀ ); ratio of pedipalpal femur/carapace 1.0–1.3 ( ♂ ♀ ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 26–32.
Chthonius alpicola Beier, 1951
, slope of Mt. Matajur (Losaz, Udine). 26, male, anterior margin of carapace; 27, female, id.; 28, male, carapace; 29, male, right chelicera; 30, female, movable finger of right chelicera; 31, male, right chelal hand, dorsal view; 32, female, id.

FIGURES 33–40.
Chthonius alpicola Beier, 1951
, slope of Mt. Matajur (Losaz, Udine). 33, male, right chela, antiaxial view; 34, male, detail of fingers at the chelal tip, antiaxial view; 35, male, detail of fingers at level of trichobothria est-it and st-t , antiaxial view; 36, male, detail of fingers at level of trichobothrium sb , antiaxial view; 37, female, right chela, antiaxial view; 38, female, detail of fingers at the chelal tip, antiaxial view; 39, female, detail of fingers at level of trichobothria est-it and st-t , antiaxial view; 40, female, detail of fingers at level of trichobothrium sb , antiaxial view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description of tritonymph. Integument with weak pigmentation, hispid granulation less marked than in adults. Carapace 0.90–0.95 times longer than broad, form of anterior margin and eyes as in adults; diameter of anterior eyes
0.032 –0.034 mm
; chaetotaxy m 4m :6:4:2:m 2m (22), rarely 2 preocular microsetae on one side; length of anteromedian macrosetae 0.07 mm . Chaetotaxy of tergites as in adults. Chaetotaxy of sternites II–IX 5:(2)8(2):(1)6(1):7:6:6:6:6. Chelicerae 1.95–2.05 times as long as broad, palm with 5 setae and 1 lateral microseta; fixed finger with 6–8 teeth, proximally reduced in size, and a few proximal microtubercles; movable finger with an isolated subapical tooth ( di ) and 6–7 teeth; gs ratio 0.57–0.60; spinneret prominent and apically rounded as in females. Coxal setae: pedipalp 5 (including 2 on manducatory process), I 3 + 2 marginal microsetae, II 4, III 5, IV 5; coxa II with 4–6 coxal spines, coxa III with 2–5 coxal spines; intercoxal tubercle bisetose. Pedipalp: femur 4.1–4.6 times as long as broad; chela 4.9–5.05 times as long as deep; hand of chela 1.7 times as long as deep; fixed chelal finger with 40–43 contiguous teeth, all with dental canal; movable chelal finger with 30–33 teeth, reduced in size towards finger base, reaching back between st and b ; coupled sensilla pc nearer to b than to st ; ratio of movable finger/hand of chela 1.9; ratio of pedipalpal femur/movable finger 1.0; ratio of pedipalpal femur/carapace 1.0–1.1.

Measurements (in mm). Body length 0.90–0.95. Carapace 0.305–0.34 × 0.32–0.37 (0.29–0.33 anteriorly). Chelicerae 0.28–0.33 × 0.14–0.16, movable finger length 0.145–0.17. Pedipalp: femur 0.31–0.37 × 0.075–0.08; chela 0.48–0.54 × 0.095–0.11; hand length 0.16–0.19; movable finger length 0.31–0.36.

Remarks. Among the Italian species with contiguous chelal teeth of the
Chthonius ischnocheles
group, the relationships of
C. alpicola
are uncertain. The presence of both preocular microsetae and lateral microsetae on the posterior margin of the carapace is shared only by highly specialised hypogean species, such as
C. italicus Beier, 1930
,
C. caoduroi Callaini, 1987
,
C. multidentatus Beier, 1963
and
C. gallettii
n. sp. (see Key to species).

The measurements given by Beier (1963c) of a female from I Moi, Entratico ( Lombardy ) (palpal hand 0.28, finger 0.55 mm length) are consistent with the above description. Callaini (1986a) referred to
Chthonius
cfr.
alpicola
three males and one female from Pradis ( Friuli ), showing a ratio sb -st/sb -b = 1.72–2.03 instead of 1.5, as reported by Beier (1951) , and est more distal than in Beier (1951: 165 , fig. 1a). The relative position of trichobothria sb and est shows a high variability in studied populations and thus the specimens from Pradis are referred to
C. alpicola
.

The above description of
Chthonius alpicola
incorporates the measurements of Callaini (1986a) . The species is newly recorded from Slovenia and Croatia .
